Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2007 06:02AM 3boys4me wrote: I'm coming to terms with the loss of my breast.  Not to say I'm totally okay with it, but I'm accepting it.  Ends up my husband did come into the exam room with me on Friday and he's dealing with it, too.  I think we'll be okay. Thank you for all of your personal stories.  It's always so helpful to hear from others and know we don't travel this road alone. Lisa
Posts.Title: accepting body after surgery 3boys4me janniexy

Posts.Content: 3boys4me wrote: I had my mastectomy last week and I can't bring it upon myself to see the area where I had a breast.  A home health nurse came by to change the dressings and I just laid there with my eyes closed and cried.  I don't know when I'll have the courage to look at myself.  I have an appointment with my surgeon on Friday to check the incision and change bandages.  My husband will take me as he as for every appointment, but this time, I don't want him to into the exam room with me.  I don't want him to see me like this and I don't think he wants to see me this way. I know it will pass, I'll be okay, he'll be okay, but right now, it's hard and I'm just an emotional wreck.  ** Live Well * Laugh Often * Love Much ** Dx 2/2007, IDC, Left, 5cm, Stage IIB, Grade 2, 6/14 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: accepting body after surgery 3boys4me janniexy

Posts.Content: Sep 14, 2007 02:38AM 3boys4me wrote: Thanks for all your kind thoughs.  I've been taking tiny peaks down my top.  I know I'll be able to face myself (my chest) in time.  Probably sooner than later and I'd really like to get a shower tomorrow when these drains come out.  I like those terms battle scar or badge of courage as this truly is a fight for life. I've spoken with my husband.  I don't want him in the doctors office tomorrow (unless he really wants to be).  Though he will be in the waiting room so I know I'm not being abandoned.  I told him he needs to let me know when he's ready to see it.  I'm sure he will be okay with it, but I want it to be on his terms when he thinks he can take it.  He's under a lot of stress right now as my mom passed away in June, I've got cancer, work is stressful, we've got 3 boys, and he quit smoking in May after I was diagnosed.  As much as I need love and nurturing, I know he does, too. Lisa
Posts.Title: accepting body after surgery 3boys4me janniexy

Posts.Content: 3boys4me wrote: I'm hoping those of you who have experienced lymphedema can answer some questions for me.  Mine cropped up about a month or so ago.  I had a unilateral mastectomy 9/6 with 14 lymph nodes removed. In October I flew.  I requested a prescription for a sleeve and gauntlet from my surgeon prior to my flight (after reading this board and the info provided by the lymphedema specialist while still in the hospital) but was basically ignored. During the same time, I was repeatedly aspirated after my drains were removed. Who knows what really brought this on, but it's here.  Luckily it early stage.  I now have a sleeve and gauntlet that I've been wearing daily.  It's ugly but not uncomfortable, so I really don't mind it as much as I thought I might. My questions are:  my lymphedema specialist said if I lost weight, the lymphedema would likely improve.  I do need to lose about 40 lbs.  Has anyone else had this recommendation and if so, has anyone been successful in losing weight and seeing improvement in the lymphedema? Also, I find that hotter and more humid weather seems to make the lymphedema worse.  Anyone else experience this? And finally, do you find you have to wear the sleeve and gauntlet EVERY day or are you able to give yourself a breather on occasion without experiencing increased swelling? I had another question, but my chemo brain seems to be causing me mental problems AGAIN.  Oh, now I remember, it's about sleeping on that side, but I'll read through the other thread as I'm sure everyone has chimed in on that question already. Sorry for the long winded post, but I've read through the threads and many of you seem so knowledgable. Thanks so much, Lisa ** Live Well * Laugh Often * Love Much ** Dx 2/2007, IDC, Left, 5cm, Stage IIB, Grade 2, 6/14 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Dec 5, 2007 01:30PM 3boys4me wrote: Thanks for all of your info.  It sounds, just like with bc treatment, that treatment for lymphedema varies from person to person. Binney - to answer your question, I did have MLD done and was taught to do self MLD which I've been doing daily.  And thank you for the link.  I have a gym membership, but would like one with an indoor pool and I've heard swimming can be helpful.      A night sleeve or wrap was not suggested to me...  but it would be nice to by LE free as oppose to just maintaining. Thanks again for your responses! Your LE sister,  Lisa

Posts.Content: Nov 2, 2007 06:52PM 3boys4me wrote: Hey ladies, Wow, so much goes on within this thread when you miss a day or two.  I'm not good on call outs, but I do want to say Evy - my heart is with you.  Going through cancer treatment is hard enough and I can't imagine being pregnant while going through treatment.  I have read other posts and I do know a woman in one of my bc support groups who is pregnant and they all seem to be bearing up well and have healthy babies.    Momma-mia - I had a similar situation, but I had 4 rounds of chemo before my lumpectomy and SNB to shrink the tumor as at the time surgery wasn't even a possiblity.  This was followed by a mastectomy and full lymph node dissection and now I'm finishing up with more chemo, then rads and tamoxifen.  Be positive in your thinking.  Treatment for BC has come so far - believe in your treatment, your doctors and yourself - believe you will be there for you family at the end of all this. Those of you who are having trouble sleeping, ask for Ativan.  I think is for anxiety, but also helps with stomach problems and helps you sleep.  I take one or two at night and it really helps without making me all weird or feeling drugged the next morning. I just had my 1st of 4 chemos yesterday followed up by my neulasta shot today.  So far so good, but I'm told days 3-4 are the worst.  I'm going to think positive that I'll not have any SE's.  Yeah, right, but I can hope!  love to all, Lisa

Posts.Content: Oct 19, 2007 01:21AM 3boys4me wrote: Speaking of the insurance, I agree, I don't know how people without insurance do it either.  I think my insurance has paid out $66K so far since the first of the year and that amount is growing daily.  I still have 4 infusions, rads, tamoxifen and reconstruction to go....  OUCH!  Of course, my deductible and co-pays kick back in on the first of January.  More out of pocket expense - major bummer, but can't complain too much when I think of the alternative. I am so dreading starting chemo again.  My hair is about 1-1/2 inches long since I stopped my first rounds of chemo back in mid-June, my nails are better than they've ever been and I just generally feel good, so the thought of going through the nausea and fatigue and metallic taste in the mouth, the mouth sores, etc., etc... again is starting to get to me.  The fluid accumulation from the mastectomy and lymph node dissection seems to be subsiding - at least to me.  Will know for sure tomorrow when I see my surgeon to see if he's going to give me the all clear sign.  love to all, Lisa

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2007 09:43PM 3boys4me wrote: Hi Suzyb855 and roach59, I was beginning to think I'd be riding this rollercoaster alone.  I'm a cross between the two of you.  I already had chemo, too and it wasn't that bad.  At its worst it was kind of like being 3 months pregnant with a slight case of the flu.  I'd feel fine for the infusion with help from the steroids, then sleep for that first weekend and be fine before the next infusion.  I, too, was fatigued and gained weight.  Figure I'll worry about all that after chemo and rads.  I had a lumpectomy on Aug 1 but my trio of doctors, surgeon, oncologist and oncology radiologist, along with the tumor board, decided a mastectomy with ancillary lymph node dissection was the best/safest route.  That was done the 6th of September.  I had my port put in at the same time and that hurt more than the mastectomy.  I'm still carrying around one drain which I hope comes out this coming Friday.  Then it's more chemo - AC for me as far as I know.  What's your cocktail? About me - I'm 46, married, live in San Diego and have 3 boys ages 10, 14 and 17.  I decided to not work during treatment which has been a blessing.  I'm Stage 2, Intermediate grade, ER/PR+, Her2/Neu -.  I know this isn't the club you ever wanted to join, but it's still nice to have others going through treatment with you. Lisa

Posts.Content: Oct 16, 2007 06:01AM 3boys4me wrote: Hi all, Just checking in.  Our family just got back from Orlando for a business/pleasure trip.  We had a conference, so pulled the boys out of school and sent them off to Universal Studios and Disney World while my husband and I worked.  Then spent a couple of days chasing alligators and checking out Kennedy Space Center.  It was good to get away. I saw my surgeon this morning and got aspirated again.  No drain though.  I'm not sure if that is good news or bad.  I go back again Friday.  I'm currently scheduled to start chemo again on the 25th, but I'm sure that date will depend on what the surgeon says this Friday. TexasKaren- it sure seems everyone's recipe is different.  From what I understand, the rule of thumb is lumpectomy and rads OR mastectomy and chemo.  I don't follow the rule as I had neo-adjuvant chemo, lumpectomy, mastectomy, and still have more chemo and rads to go.  Evy- You've got a lot to deal with.  Know you are in my thoughts and prayers as well as the thoughts and prayers of others on this board. Take care everyone, Lisa

Posts.Content: 3boys4me wrote: Just as background - I had neoadjuvant chemo which shrunk my tumors. One was DCIS, the other IDC close to the chest wall with vascular invasion. Since the chemo was so successfull, I elected to do a lumpectomy and SNB. Well, just got the pathology report back and there is possible additional lymph node involvement. At first my docs suggested a mastectomy and lymph node removal, but then they decided to send me to the oncology radiologist. They said if the radiologist was confident he could radiate the entire area they'd feel confident to go that direction. Well, the radiologist was non-committal and he suggested waiting until the they all meet this coming Tues in a tumor board to discuss my case. In my heart and mind I just want to leave things as be and get the chemo, rads and tamoxifen, but if that leaves too much risk of the cancer spreading, then logically I know I need to have the mastectomy. Then with a mastectomy comes so many more decision as to reconstruction and the length of time for treatment seems overwhelming. Thanks for listening and if you have any words of advise, please share. ** Live Well * Laugh Often * Love Much ** Dx 2/2007, IDC, Left, 5cm, Stage IIB, Grade 2, 6/14 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: not sure how to proceed 3boys4me 3boys4me

Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2007 09:37PM 3boys4me wrote: Hi Debbie,  When you get chemo prior to surgery, you feel like you are doing things bassackwards as most people you meet do things the other way around, but know it is more common than you think. I had a 5cmx3cm tumor and was put on Taxotere and Xeloda prior to surgery to shink the tumor.  It was successful as my follow up mammogram and MRI showed the tumor was gone.  I subsequently had a lumpectomy with SNB, but my doctors were still concerned that there might be tumor left.  I went on to have a mastectomy and lymph node dissection which was the right choice as I had residual cancer in my breast and 6/14 lymph nodes.  Best of luck to you on this journey and know we are here with you, Lisa

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2007 11:49AM 3boys4me wrote: Hi Elaine, The port hurt when it was put in, but now I don't notice it all.  Since I've not yet had chemo using it, I'm not sure how that will feel.  The port is an inconvenience.  It doesn't hurt, it's just in the way.  I am so looking forward to getting it removed, but I've heard if it's removed to early, it can lead to other complications like swelling and infection. I am planning on getting reconstruction.  I didn't realize I'd have to wait so long between treatments.  I know I'll be starting chemo in October for 4 cycles.  I went to a BC educational seminar yesterday and here's what I found out: I will need to wait about a month after chemo before starting radiation.  Then, I'm hearing most people have to wait at least 6 months or longer for reconstruction AND once you have radiation, implants are not a viable option and TRAM flap, LAT flap, free flap or DIEP are the options - all of them involving longer surgeries and longer recovery periods. I also just read my most recent pathology report and based on it, I'm Stage 3A, Intermediate grade.  (T2,N2,MX)  I had 6 of 14 nodes test postive along with DCIS and IDC - hence the surgery, chemo, rads, and tamoxifen. keep in touch, Lisa

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2007 01:31PM 3boys4me wrote: I got my start date so will begin 4 cycles of AC on 10/3 pending clearance from my surgeon on the 2nd.  I'm only getting 4 cycles since I already had the 4 Taxotere and Xeloda before surgery.  I'm healing nicely and have my prosthesis so am doing okay overall.  For those of you getting Taxotere, it can make you a little achey - I always described it feeling like you have a slight case of the flu between the fatigue, minor nausea (no vomiting) and achiness.  Since I knew I was having more chemo, I asked the surgeon to put in the port during the mastectomy.  Honestly, the port hurt so much worse than the mastectomy - it still bothers me a little.  I just know that 2-3 months from now, this part will be over.  I can do this - we can do this!  hugs to all of you cancer sisters, Lisa
Posts.Title: October 2007 Chemo Girls 3boys4me saucybee

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2007 04:15PM 3boys4me wrote: I'm so sorry to hear of everyone's se's.  Ah, chemo, the good and the bad.  It's good to think about the chemo killing off all those bad cells systemically, but physically, it can be difficult.  I'd forgotten about the heartburn.  It was so bad during my first 4 coursed of chemo.  Nothing worked to relieve it.  When I asked my onc about it - he said it was because my receptors were full - whatever that means.  And the facial flush - the effects of the steroids.... Having already gone through chemo once, I'd forgotten these things until you ladies brought them up again.  Now I find myself mentally preparing for my AC infusion on Wednesday. hugs to all, Lisa
Posts.Title: October 2007 Chemo Girls 3boys4me saucybee

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2007 09:13AM 3boys4me wrote: Hi ladies, I'm so sorry to hear of everyone's se's.  Chemo is a drag - that's all there is to it.  I got a reprieve until 10/17 for now.  I got my mastectomy and lymph node removal back on 9/6 and the drains removed 9/20.  I've been in twice to be aspirated as I've still got a lot of fluid accumulating.  I go back on Friday and if the fluid problem is still there, I will be getting a drain put in.  I wouldn't mind so much, but my family is flying to Florida on 10/10 for a business/pleasure trip and I really don't want to travel with a drain   Hopefully this problem will resolve on it's own over the next couple of days! Take care - I've got all of you in my thoughts and prayers, Lisa
Posts.Title: October 2007 Chemo Girls 3boys4me saucybee

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2007 04:08AM 3boys4me wrote: Hi girls, Welcome to the club you never wanted to join. Karen #2 - if you have chemo on Mondays you should be in relatively good shape by the weekend, though perhaps a little tired. Seems like most of you are dealing well with the side effects of chemo.  I'm dreading going through it again.  I was trying to plan the chemos so they don't ruin Thanksgiving and Christmas, but now I'm not sure I can control my schedule.  My chemo date has been moved to the 25th.  I'll be getting drains put back in on the 15th to help with the fluid that keeps accumulating in my chest since the mastectomy.  Hopefully the drains will dry me out so the chemo doesn't keep getting pushed back. Take care, Lisa
Posts.Title: October 2007 Chemo Girls 3boys4me saucybee

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2007 01:19AM 3boys4me wrote: I thought the norm was lumpectomy + rads OR mastecomy + chemo.  But it seems everyone is so different that the treatment is very individual.     I, too, am getting rads after mastectomy (and chemo, too).  I was told the rads were necessary because of the original size of the tumor (large) and the number of lymph nodes involved (6 out of 14).  I'm not sure about the mammogram question - though I only had a single mastectomy so I'd still have a mammogram and/or MRI at least on that side.  I'll have to ask my dr about the other side.
